Award.AwardTitle: College Ready In Math and Physics Partnership

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The College Ready in Mathematics and Physics Partnership (College Ready) is comprised of thirty-three school districts in Arkansas and Oklahoma, the University of Arkansas at Fort Smith, and the University of Arkansas, Fayetteville, which will serve as the lead among these core partners. In addition, the following are supporting partners: the American Association of Physics Teachers (AAPT), American Physical Society (APS), College Board, Mathematical Association of America (MAA), Maplesoft, Northwest Arkansas Community College (NWACC), and the UAF Center for Mathematics and Science Education (CMASE). College Ready intends to build vertical and horizontal learning communities among school and college faculty in order to improve major articulation issues that impact the successful transition of students from high school to college. College Ready focuses its work on a number of critical junctures and therefore is centered on articulation issues between school and college - teacher preparation in college for work in schools and student preparation in school for college mathematics and science - and among colleges and disciplines.

The major intents of College Ready are to:
1) Prepare students for college success, especially in STEM Areas
a. Smooth the transition to college by improved articulation
b. Provide improved placement mechanisms for college mathematics
2) Enhance teacher capacity to deliver rigorous, successful courses and
curricula
a. Build learning communities of school and college faculty
b. Sort out and negotiate competing standards and accountabilities
3) Build vertical and horizontal learning communities to improve articulation
4) Prepare teachers to serve as curriculum and pedagogy leaders who can
a. serve as peer mentors to fellow teachers
b. encourage pedagogy that is correctly connected to content, and
c. create synergism between mathematics and science classes
5) Make effective learning resources available, including the production of
supporting materials for ongoing professional development and embedded
English Language Learner (ELL) instruction
6) Strengthen pre-service education
7) Improve the number of pre- and postsecondary teachers, including
recruitment and retention.

Ultimately, College Ready will demonstrate an impact on student outcomes through decreases in college remediation rates in mathematics, increases in student proficiency scores on state assessments, increased numbers of students enrolling in Advanced Placement (AP) mathematics and physics courses and scoring 3 or better on the AP exams, and increased graduation and college-going rates.

College Ready will achieve these ends through a series of interconnected activities including vertical alignment of high school and college expectations, intensive content driven workshops, articulation conferences, university course revisions, the creation of professional learning communities, and the opportunity to earn advanced degrees and endorsements. It builds on and looks to establish synergy between established efforts of PhysTEC and PMET. The College Ready endeavors are complemented by a set of three research questions to be pursued: Is there a unifying construct in the way units are used in physics, economics, public discourse, and in 9-14 mathematics? What measures best determine college readiness and placement in mathematics, and how can placement testing in mathematics be better aligned with high school curricula? What educational opportunities influence students to choose a career in secondary physics teaching, and which elements are replicable?

POR.DRECONTENT:
The College Ready in Mathematics and Physics Partnership envisions a system that supports and sustains delivery of high-quality mathematics and physics education for all students at core partner schools and institutions in the targeted region of Arkansas and eastern Oklahoma. College Ready systematically engaged core partners, which included 39 school districts with 89 schools and two universities, for more than six years as a funded MSP. The primary venue for this engagement was the more than 2600 hours of professional development workshops for over 600 teachers, faculty, and administrators from core partners. More than 470 teachers in grades 7-12 participated in 82 workshops that increased their content and pedagogical content knowledge while equipping them with the skills necessary to function effectively in Professional Learning Communities (PLCs).

With the overarching goal of increasing college readiness in mathematics and science, College Ready used various metrics to measure impact on student preparation for college. Arkansas partner schools increased both the quantity and quality of students’ performance on AP exams. During the life of the MSP, Arkansas partner schools increased by 75.5% (494 to 867) the number of students taking the AP Calculus exam; by 185% (215 to 612) the number of students taking the AP Statistics exam; and by 135% (116 to 273) the number of students taking the AP Physics exam. As participation levels increased, so did performance on these AP exams. Arkansas partner schools increased by 91.4% (243 to 465) the number of students scoring a 3 or better on the AP Calculus exam; by 191% (81 to 236) on the AP Statistics exam; and by 225% (36 to 117) on the AP Physics exam. Across all three exams in 2013, Arkansas partner schools exceeded the national average for the percentage of students scoring a 3 or better compared to the population of high school graduates: 7.75% versus 6.35% in AP Calculus; 5.0% versus 2.66% in AP Statistics; and 3.11% versus 2.46% in AP Physics. According to ACT results, the lowest-performing partner schools in Oklahoma, defined as schools that began College Ready with mean ACT scores below 18.0, surpassed the five-year benchmark for increasing the mean mathematics ACT score by 1 point. Four schools increased their mean ACT mathematics score by an average of 1.27 points (range of 1.6 to 2.4 points). Student performance on state-mandated exams for high school students also provided an indicator of Partnership success by exceeding the benchmark of a 10 percentage point gain. Arkansas partner schools increased the percentage of students in grades 9-12 that were classified as proficient or advanced on the Algebra I End-of-Course (EOC) exam by 12.96 percentage points (66.50% to 79.46%), while also increasing this percentage on the Geometry EOC exam by 14.1 points (67.2% to 81.3%). College Ready partner schools in Oklahoma increased the percentage of students classified as proficient on the Algebra II End-of-Instruction (EOI) exam from a mean score by 47.44 percentage points (30.41% to 77.85%), and the mean score on the Geometry EOI by 20.58 percentage points (62.50% to 83.08%). College Ready also increased the number and percentage of students taking a physics course at levels that exceeded comparison group schools by margins that were found to be statistically significant. Arkansas partner schools experienced an 89.6% (626 to 1187) increase in the number of students taking a physics class in high school, while comparison schools saw a 46.0% increase.
